BC-CIR-MTV-NYT 
ON THIS MTV SHOW, VIEWERS DIRECT FROM HOME 

   By MICHEL MARRIOTT    
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   NEW YORK _ At first glance, the scene at MTV's Times Square
studio on a recent Monday afternoon was familiar to anyone who has
ever watched even a few minutes of the channel. There were music,
dancers, DJs, guest appearances and, of course, music videos. But
this show, called Direct Effect, may be anything but typical. Its
producers say that it offers a glimpse into the near future of
television for all viewers, even those who can't hold a beat in a
basket.

   Direct Effect's primary distinction from regular television fare
is that it offers viewers to not only watch it on cable television,
but to help direct it through computers wired to MTV.com. Well, at
least, they can help select _ interacting in real time _ what music
videos will be featured on the live hourlong hip-hop music show.

   ``This is perfect for our audience,'' said Sara R. Cohen, vice
president of programming for MTV.com. She described MTV's young
core audience as being ``convergent people,'' as comfortable with
their computers and cell phones as they are with their televisions.

   Once logged on to MTV.com, viewers can follow a link to Direct
Effect, where they will find three thumbnail pictures and
descriptions of the artists and videos. To vote for the next video
to be played on Direct Effect, viewers click once on a spot under
the description of the video. The vote is sent to the network's
control room in New York, where it is rapidly tabulated with
others. A running tally of the vote is posted on the live
television screen almost up to the last minute before the next
video is shown.

   ``I think the presence of this sort of show is really
reassuring,'' said Todd Boyd, a professor at the University of
Southern California's School of Cinema and Television and an expert
on hip-hop culture, ``especially when you hear so much about the
`digital divide' and large numbers of black people and minorities
being left out of the digital revolution.''

   But, he added, when one considers how increasingly comfortable
young people, all kinds of young people, are with cutting edge,
computer-based technologies like computer games and digital music,
``it's not surprising that we have reached a point where the
connection of television and the Internet is so direct.''

   Even without a computer, what viewers see on their television
screens is a blend of old-fashioned television dating back to the
days of American Bandstand and Soul Train and Web-inspired multiple
screens and banner text. In some instances as many as five screens
may compete for the viewer's attention at once.

   MTV producers and executives said that they are encouraged by
their own studies of their audience.

   ``Our audience demonstrates that it is very willing to
participate in multi-screen programs here and now,'' said Nicholas
Butterworth, president and chief executive of MTVi, the interactive
arm of MTV Networks.

   As high-speed, broadband Internet service is slowly
proliferating the United States, television and Internet executives
are increasingly promising that PC-smart, set-top boxes will one
day soon start transforming television, making much of it
interactive. Brian Graden, president of programming for MTV, said
his viewers were not willing to wait.

   ``Our audience is probably not like any other,'' added Brian
Graden, president of programming for MTV. ``About 70 percent of
them have computers and TV in the same room and use them at the
same time. They have come up with a crude two-box solution to
interactivity.''

   The MTV Networks/Viacom Study of Media, Entertainment and
Leisure Time found last summer that there has been a significant
swell in the numbers of people owning and using personal computers
in their homes. But the study also showed that television is not
losing its audience to the Internet. Instead, the two media are
co-existing.

   ``Rather than making trade-offs between different media options,
Americans are finding ways to incorporate new forms of media into
their lives without sacrificing the things they already love,''
said Betsy Frank, executive vice president for research and
planning at MTV Networks.

   In the end, she said, many people are multitasking, reflecting
something she calls ``behavioral convergence,'' which she defines
as ``people acting as if their media platforms have already
converged even though the technology isn't there yet.''
